awd_titl_txt: SYNERGIES: Customizing Interventions to Sustain Youth STEM Interest and Participation Pathways
awd_abstract_narration:
As part of its overall strategy to enhance learning in informal environments, the Advancing Informal STEM Learning (AISL) program funds innovative resources for use in a variety of settings. This research project leverages ongoing longitudinal research to investigate whether, and if so how, youth from ages 10 to 15 in a diverse, under-resourced urban community become interested and engaged in STEM. The project addresses a global issue; fewer youth choose to major in scientific fields or take science coursework at high school or university levels. These declining numbers result in fewer STEM professionals and fewer scientifically literate citizens who are able to function successfully in an increasingly scientific and technological society. These declines are observed for youth as a whole, but are most pronounced for girls and particular non-white ethnic minorities. Data collected from youth in this community of study, including non-white ethnic minorities, mirrors this decline. NSF funding will support a five-year systematic and systemic process in which project researchers work collaboratively with existing informal and formal educational partners (e.g., museums, libraries, afterschool providers, schools) to develop sets of customized, connected, and coordinated learning interventions, in and out of school, for youth with different backgrounds, needs, and interests, all with the goal of averting or dampening this decline of STEM interest and participation during early adolescence. In addition to new research and community STEM networks, this project will result in a Community Toolkit that includes research instruments and documentation of network-building strategies for use by other researchers and practitioners nationally and internationally. 

This mixed methods exploratory study has two distinct but interrelated populations - youth and educators from across informal and formal institutions. To develop a clearer understanding of the factors that influence youths' STEM interest development over time, particularly among three youth STEM Interest Profiles identified in a secondary analysis (1-Dislike Math, 2-Like all STEM, 3-Dislike all STEM), the design combines surveys with in-depth interviews and observations. To study educators and institutions, researchers will combine interviews, focus groups, and observations to better understand factors that influence community-wide, data-driven approaches to supporting youth interest development. Research will be conducted in three phases with the goal of community-level change in youth STEM interest and participation. In Phase 1 (Years 1 & 2) four educational partners will develop interventions for a 6th and 7th grade youth cohort that will be iteratively refined through a design-based approach. Educational partners and researchers will meet to review and discuss interest and participation data and use these data to select content, as well as plan activities and strategies within their programs (using a simplified form of conjecture mapping). By Phase 2 (Years 3 & 4) four additional partners will be included, more closely modeling the complex system of the community. With support from researchers support and existing partners, new educational partners will similarly review and discuss data, using these to select content, as well as plan activities consistent with program goals and strategies. Additional interventions will be implemented by the new partners and further assessed and refined with a new 6th and 7th grade cohort, along with the existing interventions of the first four partners. In Phase 3 (Year 5) data will be collected on pre-post community-level changes in STEM interest and participation and the perceived effectiveness of this approach for youth. These data will inform future studies.
org_div_long_name: Division of Research on Learning in Formal and Informal Settings (DRL)

por.por_cntn:
SYNERGIES was designed with an overarching question: Can youths' (11-14 years of age) STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics) interest/participation be positively influenced in a low-income, diverse community? The goal was to work collaboratively with educators (classroom teachers/those teaching youth outside of school/community leaders/parents) to develop customized/connected/coordinated learning experiences which we hypothesized might stop or maybe slow well-documented declines in STEM attitudes/interest/ participation between ages 11-14.

Intellectual Merit Three lines of research/practice were critical: (1) how youth become interested/participate in STEM; (2) how they build STEM learning pathways moving through varied settings in their lives; (3) how to engage out of school (OOS) educators/classroom teachers in collaborative learning design. We hoped partners would view this community as a complex learning system with STEM resources to be tapped into that re-envision innovative  learning experiences across settings/school days, weekends, and summers, in-school and OOS. Led by Oregon State University OOS STEM learning researchers, overseen by a distinguished Advisory Council, the project engaged partners in a process of carefully designing learning experiences to support/encourage deep youth STEM interest.

Broader Impacts SYNERGIES focused on improving STEM quality/broadening participation by reframing collaboration from well-intentioned individual institutions/organizations to a system-wide approachl. We purposefully chose an East Portland neighborhood because of its diversity (50 languages spoken in public schools) and low incomes among residents. Like other low-income U.S. neighborhoods, it is separated from Portland’s economically/culturally affluent areas (and resources) by natural/human-made boundaries. Only one “open” border exists with affluent Portland; it has the highest Portland crime and prostitution rates, so thereis  a social boundary. As a microcosm of urban U.S. cities, it was large enough to mirror complex social/economic dynamics of a major urban area, yet small enough to be manageable for this work. Most importantly, this community and educators, both in school/OOS, indicated a commitment to reconfiguring the neighborhood as a single, integrated learning system to improve STEM learning, generalizable to myriad other communities.

What did we learn? Despite much effort to customize/coordinate/connect youth learning interventions for the most part, we were unsuccessful. Although school administrators/teachers were excited about the ecosystem concept, they did not agree with its practice implications. We were told directly, and often, that we could design interventions for youths' OOS time, but could not interact with youth or teachers during school. Thus, efforts to engage all partners in creating ecosystem-wide interventions was thwarted by a major actor in the system.

We faced challenges trying to intervene/create coordination/connections within a STEM learning ecosystem, even a relatively small one. We focused one of our advisory meetings on the challenges we faced and received excellent advice which we acted upon, but it was not enough. We underestimated the inertia in the system; we were unable to actualize the ecosystem-scale changes we proposed. COVID-19 only exacerbated these challenges.

However, we learned about how youth build STEM learning pathways. In one study we examined three youths' learning, self-dentified as STEM-interested when we first met them. Findings show how STEM-interested youth viewed ecosystem resources and the challenges/opportunities faced in pursuit of their interests over 3 years. The analysis reinforced the unique nature of youth pathways, but also common factors. The ability of youth to move through the ecosystem depended on the availability/accessibility of in-/OOS learning resources, and support from adults (primarily parents, but also in-school/OOS teachers). This study provides insights into howcustomized/ connected/coordinated learning experiences might be structured so more youth develop enduring STEM interests. In another study we argued that to generalize and take a "whole" ecosystem approach, we must transcend individual pathways, discussing ecological constructs like productivity, durability, and resilience. Productive ecosystems were significantly influenced by the quantity/characteristics of middle school/high school/OOS learning resources available. Durable/healthy systems had long-term, connected relationships between educators/resources that supported access/participation across settings over extended time. Effective guides (teachers/informal educators/parents) played critical roles in helping youth pursue long-term interests. Resilience depended on whether resources  supporting specific interests/activities/practices were numerous and signposted effectively so that youth could find the “next” resource to sustain their interest. Findings suggest that ecosystems can be intentionally created/refined to increase the number of youths who have quality STEM experiences, and with tools/guides can construct unique/supported/connected STEM pathways. We also conducted two quantitative analyses with survey data (n= 768 youth). A longitudinal analysis examined youth clusters by interest, studying how the patterns and structure of STEM interest profiles changed over time, and how youth differed. Although effective, the analysis id not show how and why individual youth transitioned across profiles in three years, including how many youths remained in the same cluster (e.g., STEM interested). A positive finding was how unstable 6th grade STEM disinterest was; most youth moved to a more interested profile by 8th grade. Clearly also, the importance of science attitude/parental support/OOS STEM participation in moving to a more interested profile was observed.


Last Modified: 12/22/2021
Modified by: Lynn D Dierking

SYNERGIES was designed with an overarching question: Can youths' (11-14 years of age) STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics)  interest/participation be positively influenced in a low-income,  diverse community? The goal was to work collaboratively with educators  (classroom teachers/those teaching youth outside of school/community  leaders/parents) to develop customized/connected/coordinated learning  experiences which we hypothesized might stop or maybe slow  well-documented declines in STEM attitudes/interest/ participation  between ages 11-14.

Intellectual Merit Three lines of research/practice were critical: (1) how youth become  interested/participate in STEM; (2) how they build STEM learning  pathways moving through varied settings in their lives; (3) how to  engage out of school (OOS) educators/classroom teachers in collaborative  learning design. We hoped partners would view this community as a  complex learning system with STEM resources to be tapped into that  re-envision innovative  learning experiences across  settings/school days, weekends, and summers, in-school and OOS. Led by Oregon State University  OOS STEM learning researchers, overseen by a distinguished Advisory  Council, the project engaged partners in a process of carefully  designing learning experiences to support/encourage deep youth STEM interest.

Broader Impacts SYNERGIES focused on improving STEM quality/broadening participation by  reframing collaboration from well-intentioned individual  institutions/organizations to a system-wide approachl. We purposefully  chose an East Portland neighborhood because of its diversity (50  languages spoken in public schools) and low incomes among residents.  Like other low-income U.S. neighborhoods, it is separated from  Portland’s economically/culturally affluent areas (and resources) by  natural/human-made boundaries. Only one "open" border exists with  affluent Portland; it has the highest Portland crime and prostitution  rates, so thereis  a social boundary. As a microcosm of urban U.S.  cities, it was large enough to mirror complex social/economic dynamics  of a major urban area, yet small enough to be manageable for this work.  Most importantly, this community and educators, both in school/OOS,  indicated a commitment to reconfiguring the neighborhood as a single,  integrated learning system to improve STEM learning, generalizable to  myriad other communities.

What did we learn? Despite much effort to customize/coordinate/connect youth  learning interventions for the most part, we were unsuccessful. Although  school administrators/teachers were excited about the ecosystem  concept, they did not agree with its practice implications. We were told  directly, and often, that we could design interventions for youths' OOS  time, but could not interact with youth or teachers during school.  Thus, efforts to engage all partners in creating ecosystem-wide interventions was thwarted by a major actor in the system.

We faced challenges trying to intervene/create  coordination/connections within a STEM learning ecosystem, even a  relatively small one. We focused one of our advisory meetings on the  challenges we faced and received excellent advice which we acted upon,  but it was not enough. We underestimated the inertia in the system; we  were unable to actualize the ecosystem-scale changes we proposed.  COVID-19 only exacerbated these challenges.

However, we learned about how youth build STEM learning pathways. In  one study we examined three youths' learning, self-dentified as  STEM-interested when we first met them. Findings show how  STEM-interested youth viewed ecosystem resources and the  challenges/opportunities faced in pursuit of their interests over 3  years. The analysis reinforced the unique nature of youth pathways, but  also common factors. The ability of youth to move through the ecosystem  depended on the availability/accessibility of in-/OOS learning  resources, and support from adults (primarily parents, but also  in-school/OOS teachers). This study provides insights into  howcustomized/ connected/coordinated learning experiences might be  structured so more youth develop enduring STEM interests. In another  study we argued that to generalize and take a "whole" ecosystem  approach, we must transcend individual pathways, discussing ecological  constructs like productivity, durability, and resilience. Productive  ecosystems were significantly influenced by the quantity/characteristics  of middle school/high school/OOS learning resources available.  Durable/healthy systems had long-term, connected relationships between  educators/resources that supported access/participation across  settings over extended time. Effective guides (teachers/informal  educators/parents) played critical roles in helping youth pursue  long-term interests. Resilience depended on whether resources   supporting specific interests/activities/practices were numerous and  signposted effectively so that youth could find the "next" resource to  sustain their interest. Findings suggest that ecosystems can be  intentionally created/refined to increase the number of youths who have  quality STEM experiences, and with tools/guides can construct  unique/supported/connected STEM pathways. We also conducted two  quantitative analyses with survey data (n= 768 youth). A longitudinal  analysis examined youth clusters by interest, studying how the patterns  and structure of STEM interest profiles changed over time, and how youth  differed. Although effective, the analysis id not show how and why  individual youth transitioned across profiles in three years, including how many youths remained in the same cluster (e.g., STEM interested). A positive finding was how unstable 6th grade STEM disinterest was; most youth moved to a more interested profile by 8th grade. Clearly also, the importance of science attitude/parental  support/OOS STEM participation in moving to a more interested profile  was observed.
